snippet: The municipal government of Guangzhou, a sprawling metropolis that is one of China's biggest auto manufacturing centers, has introduced license plate auctions and lotteries that will roughly halve the number of new cars on the streets. The crackdown...
abstract: The municipal government of Guangzhou, a sprawling metropolis that is one of China's biggest auto manufacturing centers, has introduced license plate auctions and lotteries that will roughly halve the number of new cars on the streets. The crackdown by China's third-largest city is the most restrictive in a series of moves by the mainland's mega-cities to put quality-of-life issues ahead of short-term economic growth, something the central government has struggled to do on a national scale.

headline.main: China's No. 3 Metropolis Moves to Limit New Cars
